Elden Ring felt like it’s the culmination of all FromSoftware games that came before it. It’s everything they learned from them and more. If you’ve played other FromSoftware games, you’ll stumble upon a lot of familiar things, scenarios, locations, enemies, bullshit, and they took all that and put it in a huge open world map.

The map itself is vague. If you like the “zero hands holding” approach, this is your game. Not only do you not know what to do next, but things are hard as they are in your average souls experience, you wander into the wrong neighborhood, and there goes all your runes.

This is the most polished experience from the series. It’s visually beautiful and beautifully crafted, the world has much variety, some copy pasted landmarks but also lots of unique places with good interiors and architecture. I know some people complain that some enemies repeat, but even with that, there are tons of variety in this aspect as well.

Unlocked new fear of insects, centipedes, ants, fingers? They replaced spiders with fingers, and I don't know which is worse now... 

I have mixed feelings about the gameplay. For most people, they nailed the combat in this one, and it's true, but there are some annoying things. 

Unlike DS2, you can attack and dodge quite a lot before running out of stamina, which promotes faster gameplay, and that's usually what people seek and enjoy. To balance that, bosses also unleash a fury of successive fast attacks, and sometimes the window during which you can attack without being punished is really small, so the fight ends up with more downtime (defense time) than attacking, and that can be boring. 

I'm not talking about op builds and cheeses, those exist, but I'm speaking of a normal first playthrough experience. 

It feels like mobs don't have a stamina bar as u do. That was a nice feature from Nioh, being able to see the enemy's stamina bar. 

Another issue is how huge bosses are, now it's not new, but man, it's becoming ridiculous. I know people loove to fight big bosses, but I use M&K because I like complete camera control, and even then, I don't even see all the boss. Some fights I don't see the hit because it's impossible to have all the boss within the camera frame, neither by locking the view nor by unlocking it. 

Other than that, I absolutely love the animations, the weapon variety, the spell effects, the class variety, and mix and matching, all the new features are fun to play with. 

On a more personal note, even though this game has everything, even things from previous souls games, more features, more work into it, I still think that experiencing similar features was more iconic in previous titles. If you're new to the genre, this game is a fantastic place to start. It has everything, and it's modern, but for me, I still find DS1 to be the most iconic and the most beautiful journey, but maybe cause I played it first, we will never know.

Its easily one of the most absorbing and punishing open world RPG game where you play the role of a 'victim' hehe. The Lands Between feels like a mystery full of hidden caves, ruins and half the time I felt like I was discovering things by accident lol.
Combat is a classic FromSoftware brutality, but with more freedom than ever. I went with a Crit twin-dagger parry build and it honestly felt so cool to learn enemy moves and parry them into a one-shot kill, other times realizing I'd just nerfed myself into oblivion. The bosses were where the real struggle kicked in. I’ll admit it: I got absolutely demolished by Margit the first time, and not in a “haha that was tough” way more like “I think this game hates me personally.” Godrick turned the arena into a tornado of panic rolls. Radahn ? I think I died so many times I started recognizing the shape of each meteor he called down on me.
Exploration was just as chaotic for me. I kept wandering into areas I had no business being in Caelid destroyed me, the underground cities confused me, and I’m pretty sure I fell off cliffs more times than I actually died to enemies.
The story, while cryptic, drew me in heavily. The more I played, the more I wanted to piece together the lore and untangle the tragedy of the Lands Between. Even when I was frustrated or exhausted, that curiosity pushed me forward.
In the end, Elden Ring made me feel everything - excitement, fear, confusion and pure stubbornness. It challenged me constantly, but that’s exactly what made finally beating its toughest encounters feel so incredible. It’s one of the few games where struggling through it actually deepened my appreciation for just how brilliantly it’s crafted.

Temos também as invocações, que ajudam muito nos chefes (principalmente o Mímico).
Agora o jogo é mundo aberto, e contamos com Torrente como montaria para nos locomover mais rápido, além da possibilidade de combate montado. E falando do mapa: o design é sensacional, variado e extremamente detalhado, com muuuuuitos tipos de inimigos.

There's so much great about this game, and so much terrible!  The great:[list]
[*]Combat is great!  It's got depth, it's challenging, and mostly it's fair.  There's a big variety of enemies (though they still get a little repetitive thanks to the sheer size of the game) and a huge variety of weapons to kill them with.
[*]Exploration is about as good as it gets.  Any cliff could have a ledge below it you might jump down to.  A large tree could be hiding a door into a cave.  Illusionary walls seemed a bit cheap at first, but there are often 'tells' like sounds coming from the other side of them.  Entire maps can be hidden away where many players can miss them!  Note that the online option can spoil this badly, though.  It's hardly a secret door when there are half a dozen messages around it telling you it's there.
[*]Art direction is great, too.  Technically, the graphics don't seem to be using the most advanced technology, but the artists did very well with what they had.
[*]Boss fights are well done.  When you beat a boss, it typically won't take even five minutes.  Of course, many of them will require some experimentation, which does mean dying and starting again a few times, but there will also be some you're particularly well suited for that will finish on your first try.  Battles against dragons can take longer, but they're also incredibly good fights with the dragons flying off a short distance and breathing fire (or whatever) at you.
[/list]

On the not-so-good side:[list]
[*]Quests.  Yeeesh!  I guess the fun of the quests came in the early days when the game was released, and the community was working together to figure them out.  If you want to follow them yourself, you'll NEED to look up guides because the NPCs have a habit of moving around a lot - and I don't mean just from one side of town to another.  The rewards, if there are any, can be pretty weak or really strong... unless it doesn't fit your build, which it often will not.
[*]Story.  There IS a story in this game, but you have to dig it out by reading item descriptions and thinking about what you're seeing.  If you're an investigative reporter or historian, you'll like sifting it out.  For everyone else... lots of hassle for very little reward.
[*]You know how those old JRPGs before, oh, 2005 or so would always make you keep talking to an NPC over and over until their dialog repeats to find out everything they want to say?  FromSoft still thinks it's a good idea.
[*]There's zero lip syncing, too.  NPCs jaws just flap away until they finish.
[*]Tone is incredibly bleak.  Could somebody please be happy!?  Preferably not because you ripped off some poor sod's skin.
[*]Every time you gain a level you get to add one point to one statistic.  You'll likely gain a good 130+ levels over the course of the game so you will definitely advance in power, but every step is tiny.  For me, at least, that takes away some of the fun.  I like to be able to see a difference after gaining a level - maybe not a big one, but something I can at least notice.
[/list]

The game's difficulty isn't quite what I thought.  If you die, you drop all your runes.  Runes are money in this game, but keep in mind that gaining levels costs runes.  They will stay roughly where you died and, as long as you come back and pick them up before dying again, there's no penalty except for the time it took you to get from the last save point to that location.  So, when you see a challenge ahead, you're going to very much want to put it off until just after you buy a level or otherwise deplete your rune count.

The game is a one-save-only style game.  As such, you'll want to back up your save just in case something goes wrong.  I never heard of any game bugs corrupting a save, but computers can do weird things, and it only takes a few seconds.  The game saves itself very often quitting the game will save in that spot.  I wouldn't try doing it in the middle of a boss fight, but those fights almost always end inside of five minutes.  The game won't do well if you need to quit at any second, but if you can get 5 minutes notice, you should be fine.

All in all, I very much enjoyed the game.  I [b]really[/b] loved the exploration.  (If you're an explorer type gamer, don't worry too much about the difficulty - you'll spend so much time exploring everything that you'll be over-levelled soon enough.)  People that love deep action combat should try the game, too.  If you're more into the stories that RPGs can tell, though, this isn't your game.

A spectacular experience the first time, and a good one in subsequent playthroughs. Elden Ring is a masterful demonstration of From Software's formula crafted into the open world. Although, this game is no masterpiece, like any other game, it holds its own significant flaws. To call it a masterpiece detracts from its problems, giving its developers the illusion that they need not make improvements. It is regressive to consider any game perfect but I dare say Elden Ring approaches perfection. However, the game does suffer from major problems. 

The multiplayer component is lackluster. The implementation of limiting gameplay with friends is a mistake. Ideally, cooperative gameplay should be seamless in the exploration of this beautiful world, without the loops and hurdles required to do so. And yes, there is a great mod for that but modders are not responsible for fixing your bad implementation (I'm looking at you Bethesda). 

The weapon upgrade system has confusing dynamics. Often times upgrading base weapons with several smithing stones, in several tiers, is more challenging than upgrading unique weapons with somber smithing stones. Upgrading base weapons takes a total of 12 smithing stones per tier compared to the 1 somber smithing stone for unique weapons. Finding and grinding smithing stones can be its own difficulty, made even easier for unique weapons considering you only need 1. The system is backwards in my opinion and should be reversed. Simply put, the base weapons should be easier to upgrade than the unique ones. 

The most gigantic issue I have with this games design is its restrained style story telling. Giving the player little instruction creates a magnificently quiet atmosphere, unlike any other game, but it's not without trade-offs. While the quite can be breathtaking, it leaves so much to be desired for quest lines. Most of the time you'll find yourself using external resources for quest progression, item locations, weapon locations, etc. While some of those features are fine, its disastrous for story telling. You are nigh-on forced to look up quest progression beyond blind luck which has the effect of utterly ripping you out the experience. You'll be sooner be checking off a guided list of instructions on a YouTube guide or Wiki page than naturally progression the story. The problem is compounded when you need to complete these vague quest lines for different ending. While solutions are something I cannot easily provide, From should look to compromising between the baby mode of Rockstar missions and the quiet restraint that From is known for. 

Overall, disagree with my points as you like, but we need to be more critical of games. It's easily to clown on utter failures, but its far worse to relentlessly praise a great game. We cannot give From Software the idea that they are infallible. It's happened before, and now look at Bethesda's output. We should recognize and voice our issues without strictly praising a great game. Consequently, From Software will continue to improve and we will continue to play their great games. I don't want to continue in a market suffocated by underachievement and disappointment. A market that From Software has stood above, time and time again.

Maybe my favorite FromSoft title (in competition with Bloodborne), Elden Ring is the most ambitious of the Soulsborne games and it's an ambition that pays off. The world of the Lands Between is an addicting place and the sheer freedom and variety of combat and builds alone would mark this as one of my favorites. In my opinion, boss design is the best it's ever been in Elden Ring  with all of the main boss fights (and a lot of the optional) being incredibly memorable. Lore wise, Elden Ring has surpassed even Dark Souls with its complexity and depth and I love how it has it's own unique feel and tone just like the original Dark Souls.

Now that I'm (mostly) done praising it, here are some issues I have. ER reuses a lot of boss assets for optional bosses, to a point where it's very noticeable and feels a bit lazy. Elden Ring was the first game I ever platinumed, and for a long time I considered it the peak of gaming. After exploring other titles, it has not aged as flawlessly for me, but I still hold it in high regard and would recommend it to anyone who enjoys a true open world experience. Unlike games that feel empty or overly curated, Elden Ring delivers scale, density, and meaningful exploration.

The world is rich in story, but the game does not convey its narrative in a traditional way. Most of the lore must be pieced together through item descriptions, environmental clues, and supplementary YouTube explanations. Without that extra effort, you are often left unsure of what is happening or why. The absence of quest markers adds to the sense of freedom, but it also makes it very easy to lock quests, miss key items, or unknowingly cut yourself off from certain endings.

In terms of difficulty, I never found the game overwhelming. The only encounter that felt significantly demanding was Messmer in the DLC. The game allows you to farm levels freely and exploit a variety of strategies that make many bosses manageable. I am a dexterity-focused player and used one katana (Nagakiba) for most of the game. I parried Malenia on my first attempt, which is why I find it amusing that some content creators dramatize dozens or hundreds of attempts using mage builds.

The build system is another point of friction. While the number of options is impressive, it can be stressful to navigate such a wide range of possibilities. A more intuitive structure would have made experimentation less overwhelming.

Graphically, the game is solid, but it is not exceptional. Older titles like God of War (2018) still surpass it visually, especially on PC.

Despite its flaws, Elden Ring is absolutely worth playing. It offers a unique sense of discovery and scale that few games achieve. Just avoid turning it into your entire identity. Step away, get some perspective, and enjoy it alongside other great titles.

This review is a bunch of nitpicking but the more I go back and play the older From games the more I'm disappointed with this game:

The open world itself is forgettable since it poses zero challenge to the player.  You can just turn your brain off and run past every enemy with zero punishment. People still reminisce about their first time in Blight Town or facing those two guys down the well in Bloodborne. There is literally nothing of sort in Elden Ring.

The small dungeons spread out in the open world sometimes have interesting gimmicks but usually end with you killing a reused boss and being rewarded something you'll never end up using. Bloodborne chalices had random layouts, a decent amount of  enemies/bosses not in the regular game and gave you a reason to do them in Blood gems. All that and most people still skipped them. Ubisoft level bloat for people who don't realize more playtime doesn't make a game better. 

Legacy dungeons, you don't even want to explore because after doing a few you realize the only decent content the game has are the bosses. DS1 was praised for the inteconnected world, DS2 and 3 still had shortcuts you could discover by exploring.  The level design once again devolved with ER, with a grace around every corner the shortcuts and the relief from finally finding one are mostly gone. 

Bosses, I've died to Malenia, Messmer and Radahn dozens of times yet none of them gave me the same dopamine hit from killing Gael or Orphan in maybe one fifth of the tries. It feels like 90% of the challenge with all these big bad bosses are their one or two crazy moves. You'll die over and over to Waterfowl or the big snake combo Messmer has until you figure out when and which way to roll or run. You'll never get that adrenaline rush from getting a boss to 5-10% your first try because these moves solely exist to make older players not whine about everything else by giving the illusion of difficulty while still letting the new "broader audience" tank half the combos with their summon. This contrast in difficulty between the world and the bosses also makes the game feel like a boss rush rather than an adventure like the older games.

Narrative, they don't leave things to imagination much compared to the older games. Ranni probably blogs more about the story than the entirety of DS1 dialogue. Around the same amount of NPC questlines in a much bigger world makes the world feel even more barren. Through 3 playthroughs I haven't noticed a Solaire, Lucatiel or Anri. Someone on a similar journey, living their own life you come across multiple times. Maybe they exist but the world isn't interesting enough for me to go find them.

Multiplayer, covenants are gone, invasions are opt-in. All the fun sucked out of it because god forbid the people who already look up everything online would have to look up how to turn invasions off too.

It's still an okay game but I'm worried where FromSoft is heading. I don't care if some guy who didn't have the dedication to beat the older games now gets to have fun beating bosses with spells/summons/weapon arts as long as it doesn't end up making the game a worse experience but the multiple steps backwards taken in level/world design, narrative, multiplayer are clearly an attempt to make the game more appealing to them, and it affects everyone.

The most overrated game of all time.

Let me be clear: I don’t mind difficulty. In fact, I’ve loved challenging games since childhood. I enjoy learning from my mistakes, improving, dying, trying again, and beating bosses. I defeated 30–40 bosses in Elden Ring without giving up, raging, or complaining about the difficulty.

My issue is not difficulty, it’s everything else.

Story & Worldbuilding

Yes, the world of Elden Ring can be huge, rich, and deep. But a world that big shouldn’t be this vague. The “story” basically consists of a guy shouting at the beginning and a handful of cryptic NPCs who talk like they’re solving riddles. That’s simply not for me.

I want to engage with a story.
I want an actual script, a main quest that makes sense, something to pull me into the world.
I shouldn’t have to check item descriptions or chase random weird NPCs across a massive map just to understand the basics of the lore. (Lore of the world, not the story)

Some players enjoy that style and that’s completely fine, but I don’t.

Gameplay.....

This is where the game completely loses me.

Elden Ring still uses the same old formula from 2007: slow, clunky, roll–dodge–hit combat that becomes extremely repetitive after a while. After a masterpiece like Sekiro, I genuinely thought FromSoftware would push their combat systems forward. Instead, they went backward.

Sure, there are tons of builds and creative options. But at the end of the day, every boss fight ends up feeling like you're just a rolling Pokémon waiting for openings. It’s uninteresting and dull.

Visuals & Exploration

I’ll give credit where it’s due: visually and structurally, the world is stunning. I normally hate getting lost in video games, but Elden Ring’s worldbuilding makes exploration rewarding, every corner has something to discover, and that’s a huge positive.

But in the end, amazing exploration doesn’t mean much when:

1)The story gives you nothing to hold onto, and

2)The combat system feels boring and outdated.

Conclusion

I respect people who love this game, everyone has different tastes. But I genuinely cannot see the appeal. After 42 hours of boredom, I have to drop it midway.

No vote in order to bring it closer to what I think it should be. Game is maybe 7/10, especially for a souls game. The trouble with it is that's extremely bloated and far overstays its welcome by drawing things out. It's an enormous kiddie pool with a lot of empty space and not a lot of depth. What you end up with is an experience where you spend most of your time traveling without a lot of action, hit up the necessary bosses and encounters, and make a few pit stops along the way for the things you need while ignoring the roughly 80% of the bland, recycled, and obnoxious filler. There's some 400 weapons and of those weapons maybe 10-20% ever get used. Bosses get repeated often and minor locations are very dull and uninteresting. 

The pacing is also incredibly bi-polar. The first few locations are a breeze, Things pick up a little bit at a time getting into the middle of the game, around the point where you're getting through the capitol. After that things dive off a cliff. Bosses start becoming extremely unforgiving with 9 hit wombo combos, massively inflated damage, and speed and mobility that make them a miserable chore to fight. Regular enemies too gain a jump in health, damage, and poise making them suck considerably more. I've completed this game several times now and every time I want to do a run through I hit a wall right after the capitol where my motivation to continue drops because I remember how unpleasant the last chunk is. There are some exceptions but largely the last third feels rushed and poorly tuned.

I don’t enjoy open world games, so when I saw that Fromsoft was making “open world” dark souls, I feared the worst. My fears were not only met, but surpassed. I don’t foresee myself playing any new title from Fromsoft if they keep trying to take their aging combat system and continue to duct tape Devil May Cry bosses into it. My issues with this game are legion, but I’ll just list off the most poignant ones.

- Enemies can and WILL input read you, and retaliate with frame perfect precision.
- Enemies can and WILL be put around corners to deal cheap chip damage.
-Enemies can and WILL do combos that dole out multi hit flurries of attacks that take upwards of 5-8 seconds, that you absolutely CAN’T punish afterwards as the combo actually had another 2-3 hits if you stood near them.
- Enemies can and WILL use that “ONE” attack, again and again until you die.
- Quest progression is basically impossible to keep track of without a notepad handy as the game lacks a basic quest log.
- Progress feels like it resets at the mid-end game due to enemy attacks dealing exponentially more damage.
- Certain rewards in dungeons can be completely useless for your build (Thanks open world game design!).

This applies to the DLC as well, but cranked up to 20 as you’ll need to get your Scat-du blessing up to level 20 if you intend to have any fun with this DLC. Gotta love arbitrary difficulty tied directly to world exploration that gets hindered by said enemies blocking your exploration, but hey! Game design is hard.
